thoughts.a: The input and output grids are the same sizes. The input grid contains mostly aqua color background, but also has a squiggly path of green tiles, along with a regular pattern of spaced red tiles in a horizontal line nearby the squiggly green path. There is also another regular pattern of spaced green tiles in a horizontal line below the spaced red tiles. The output grid is very similar to the input grid with the exception that there is an additional red squiggly line near the spaced green horizontal lines. In fact, this squiggly red line is a mirror copy of the squiggly green line, after it was reflective over the horizontal axis established by the center between the two horizontal spaced tile lines. We note the connection between the color of the spaced lines and the color of the squiggly paths on the opposite side of the mirror symmetry. Thus the hypothesis is the following. The input grid will contain a background color, probably aqua. It will also contain a spaced horizontal or vertical line of some color, along with a nearby squiggly path of a different color that directly touches that spaced tile horizontal or vertical line. There will also be a different second horizontal or vertical spaced tile line that has the same color as the squiggly path. In order to construct the output grid, which is the same size as the input grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is and additionally add a mirror copy of the squiggly path in the same color as the horizontal or vertical spaced line that is on the other side of the mirror axis of symmetry, whose exact location and orientation will depend on the location and orientations of the two spaced lines. In this case, those two colors were red and green and the lines were horizontal, but the colors could be whatever two non-background colors that show up.
thoughts.b: The input grid contains a yellow background color and two vertical spaced lines, one blue and one red. In this case, the spaced lines are vertical instead of horizontal. There is also a squiggly path of blue tiles in the input grid that goes from the top to the bottom. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is with the addition of a new mirrored copy of the squiggly path of the appropriate color. This new squiggly path should be the same color as one of the two spaced vertical lines, specifically the one on the other side of the mirror axis of symmetry. In this case it should be red, because the red spaced tile is on the other side of the mirror axis of symmetry. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid, the hypothesis holds. We also are confident now that the background color can be any color and the mirror axis of symmetry may be either horizontal or vertical.
thoughts.c: We apply the hypothesis here. The input grid contains a green color background and two vertical spaced lines, one blue and one yellow. In this case, the spaced lines are vertical. There is also a squiggly path of yellow tiles in the input grid that goes from the top to the bottom edge of the input grid. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid as is with the addition of a new mirrored copy of the squiggly path of the appropriate color. This new squiggly path should be the same color as one of the two spaced vertical lines, specifically the one on the other side of the mirror axis of symmetry. In this case, the new mirror path should be blue, because the blue spaced tile line is on the other side of the mirror axis of symmetry. We should ensure that the new blue squiggly path is relatively the same as the yellow squiggly path after having been mirrored over the vertical axis of symmetry.
